{{Inadequate lead|date=April 2015}}
'''[[Sexual violence]]''' includes, but is not limited to [[rape]]. Although there is no agreed upon definition of sexual violence, commonly applied ones encompass any act of a sexual nature or attempt to obtain a sexual act carried out through coercion. Sexual violence also includes physical and psychological violence directed at a person's sexuality, including unwanted comments or advances, or acts of traffic such as forced [[prostitution]] or [[sexual slavery]].<ref>[WHO (2002), 'Sexual violence', in World Report in violence and health, Chapter 6, pp. 149]</ref><ref>[Elements of Crimes, Article 7(1)(g)-6 Crimes against humanity of sexual violence, elements 1. Accessed through {{cite web |url=http://www.icc-cpi.int/en_menus/icc/legal%20texts%20and%20tools/official%20journal/Pages/elements%20of%20crimes.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150506063708/http://www.icc-cpi.int/en_menus/icc/legal%20texts%20and%20tools/official%20journal/Pages/elements%20of%20crimes.aspx |archivedate=2015-05-06 |df= }}]</ref><ref>[McDougall, Ms. Gay J. (1998), Special Rapporteur, Contemporary forms of slavery: systematic rape, sexual slavery and slavery-like practices during armed conflict, Final report submitted by Ms. Jay J. McDougall, Special Rapporteur, E/CN.4/Sub.2/1998/13, para. 21]</ref>
Sexual violence, in times of peace and armed conflict situations, is widespread and considered to be one of the most traumatic, pervasive, and most common violations human beings suffer.<ref name="Lindsey2001">{{cite book|last=Lindsey|first=Charlotte|title=Women facing war|year=2001|publisher=ICRC|location=Geneva|pages=57–61}}</ref><ref name="icrc">{{cite web|title=Advancement of women: ICRC statement to the United Nations, 2013|url=http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/statement/2013/united-nations-women-statement-2013-10-16.htm|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref> It is a serious public health and human rights problem and has profound short- and long- term impacts on physical and mental health. Though women and girls suffer disproportionately from this kind of violence, it can occur to anybody at any age. It is also an act of violence that can be perpetrated by parents, caregivers, acquaintances, and strangers, as well as intimate partners. Sexual violence is rarely a crime of passion; it is an aggressive act that frequently aims to express power and dominance over the victim.
Sexual violence remains highly stigmatized in all settings; thus, levels of disclosure of the assault vary between regions. In general, it is widely under-reported; thus, available data tend to underestimate the true scale of the problem. In addition, sexual violence is also a neglected area of research; thus, deeper understanding of the issue is needed to promote a coordinated movement against it. It is important to distinguish between domestic sexual violence and conflict-related sexual violence.<ref>[Human Security Report (2012), Sexual Violence, Education and War: Beyond the mainstream narrative, Human Security Research Group, Simon Fraser University, Canada, Human Security Press]</ref> Often, people who coerce their spouses into sexual acts believe their actions are legitimate because they are married. In times of conflict, sexual violence tends to be an inevitable repercussion of warfare trapped in an ongoing cycle of impunity.<ref>{{cite book|last=International Committee of the Red Cross|title=Women and War|year=2008|publisher=ICRC|location=Geneva|page=12}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|title=The shame of war: sexual violence against women and girls in conflict|year=2007|publisher=OCHA/IRIN Publication|pages=57–75}}</ref> Rape is often used as a weapon of war, as a form of attack on the enemy, typifying the conquest and degradation of its women or men or captured fighters of any gender.<ref>Swiss S et al. Violence against women during the Liberian civil conflict. Journal of the American Medical Association, 1998, 279:625–629.</ref>
Even though [[international humanitarian law]] (IHL) strongly prohibits sexual violence in all armed conflicts and [[international human rights law]] (IHRL) and [[international customary law]] strongly prohibit it at all times, enforcement mechanisms are fragile or do not exist in many parts of the world.<ref name="Lindsey2001" /><ref name="icrc" /><ref name="Physicians2002">{{cite book|last=Physicians for Human Rights|title=War-related sexual violence in Sierra Leone : a population-based assessment : a report|year=2002|publisher=Physicians for Human Rights|location=Boston, MA|isbn=1-879707-37-3}}</ref><ref name="United2007">{{cite book|last=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|title=The shame of war: sexual violence against women and girls in conflict|year=2007|publisher=OCHA/IRIN Publication}}</ref> Acts of sexual violence can be charged as a [[crime against humanity]], [[genocide]], [[war crime]], or grave breach of the [[Geneva Conventions]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Bassiouni|first=M. Cherif|title=The Commission of Experts established pursuant to Security Council resolution 780 : Investigating violations of international humanitarian law in the former Yugoslavia|year=1996|publisher=International Human Rights Law Institute, DePaul University|location=Chicago, IL|isbn=1-889001-01-5|page=31}}</ref>
== International humanitarian law ==
{{rquote|right| In no other area is our collective failure to ensure effective protection for [[civilians]] more apparent – and by its very nature more shameful – than in terms of the masses of women and girls, but also boys and men, whose lives are destroyed each year by sexual violence perpetrated in conflict.| [[Ban Ki-moon]]<ref>{{cite web|author1=Ban Ki-moon|title=Report of the Secretary-General on the protection of civilians in armed conflict (S/2007/643)|url=http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/Civilians%20S2007643.pdf|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref>}}
References to sexual offences and violence provided in IHL instruments are only partially expressed in the [[1949 Geneva Conventions]], and even more vaguely considered in the 1977 Additional Protocols.<ref>[http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/misc/additional-protocols-1977.htm%20 1977 Additional Protocols]. Retrieved 9 April 2015.</ref><ref name="Lindsey2001" /> By prohibiting sexual violence in a non-discriminatory manner, [[international humanitarian law]] ensures that women are protected through a two-tiered approach, being covered by general (equal protection as men) and specific protections. IHL mandates special protections to women, according to their additional needs in situations in which they find themselves more vulnerable, for example women who are widows, sick and wounded, migrants, internally displaced, or held in detention.<ref name="icrc_a">{{cite web|title=Customary IHL. Rule 134 on Women|url=http://www.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v1_cha_chapter39_rule134?OpenDocument&highlight=134|publisher=ICRC|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable"
|- ! Instrument !! Relevant provisions !! Relevant citations or additional information |- | [[Customary law]] || [http://www.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v1_cha_chapter32_rule93 Rule 93] || State practice establishes '''prohibition of rape and other forms of sexual violence as a norm of customary international law'''. |- | [[Customary law]] || [http://www.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v1_rul_rule94%20 Rule 94] || Under the Statute of the International Criminal Court, '''sexual slavery is a war crime in both international and non-international armed conflicts'''. |- | [[Customary law]] || [http://www.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v1_cha_chapter39_rule134?OpenDocument&highlight=134%20 Rule 134] || The practice collected with regard to the specific needs of women is reinforced by and should be viewed in the light of the specific practice relating to t'''he prohibition of sexual violence and the obligation to separate women deprived of their liberty from men, as well as the prominent place of women’s rights in human rights law'''. |- | [[Customary law]] || [https://ihl-databases.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v1_rul_rule156 Rule 156] || Serious violations of international humanitarian law constitute war crimes. '''Sexual violence as a war crime'''. |- | [http://www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/publications/icrc-002-0173.pdf Geneva Conventions of 1949] || [http://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/Article.xsp?action=openDocument&documentId=BAA341028EBFF1E8C12563CD00519E66 Common Article 3] || (...) the following acts are and shall remain prohibited at any time and in any place whatsoever with respect to the above-mentioned persons: (a) violence to life and person, in particular murder of all kinds, '''mutilation, cruel treatment and torture'''; (...) (c) '''outrages upon personal dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment'''; (...) |- | [http://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/Treaty.xsp?documentId=AE2D398352C5B028C12563CD002D6B5C&action=openDocument Geneva Convention relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War] || [http://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/Article.xsp?action=openDocument&documentId=FFCB180D4E99CB26C12563CD0051BBD9 Article 27(2)] || (…) '''Women''' shall be especially protected against '''any attack on their honour, in particular against rape, enforced prostitution, or any form of indecent assault.''' (...) Without prejudice to the provisions relating to their state of health, age and sex, all protected persons shall be treated with the same consideration by the Party to the conflict in whose power they are, without any adverse distinction based, in particular, on race, religion or political opinion (…). |- | [http://www.icrc.org/ihl.nsf/INTRO/470 Additional Protocol I] || [http://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/Article.xsp?action=openDocument&documentId=086F4BB140C53655C12563CD0051E027 Article 75(2) (b)] || (...) outrages against personal dignity, in particular humiliating and '''degrading treatment, enforced prostitution and any other form of sexual assault''' (…) |- | [http://www.icrc.org/ihl.nsf/INTRO/470 Additional Protocol I] || [http://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/Article.xsp?action=openDocument&documentId=5FB5CC7AD1C3AAF7C12563CD0051E08C Article 76(1)] || '''Women''' shall be the object of special respect and shall be protected '''in particular against rape, forced prostitution and any other form of indecent assault'''. (…) |- | [http://www.icrc.org/ihl.nsf/INTRO/470 Additional Protocol I] || [http://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/ART/470-750099?OpenDocument Article 77(1)] || '''Children''' shall be the object of special respect and shall be protected against '''any form of indecent assault''' |- | [http://www.icrc.org/ihl.nsf/INTRO/475?OpenDocument Additional Protocol II] || [http://www.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/Article.xsp?action=openDocument&documentId=F9CBD575D47CA6C8C12563CD0051E783 Article 4(2) (e)] || Prohibition of outrages against personal dignity, in particular '''humiliating and degrading treatment, rape, enforced prostitution and any other form of indecent assault''' |}
== International criminal law ==
{{rquote|right|[[Rape]] and other forms of sexual violence that amount to serious violations of international humanitarian law entail [[Criminal responsibility|individual criminal responsibility]] and must be prosecuted. All States are obliged to criminalize these violations under [[domestic law]], and to effectively investigate and prosecute any instance of sexual violence.| [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC)<ref name="icrc" />}}
Although evidence of sexual atrocities such as [[mass rape]]s is acknowledged in the [[Nuremberg War Crimes Tribunal]] and [[Tokyo Tribunal]], references to sexual violence in their respective charter are absent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sexual Violence and Armed Conflict: United Nations Response|url=https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/public/cover.pdf|accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref> Nonetheless, the [[International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda]] (ICTR), the [[International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY), the hybrid [[Special Court for Sierra Leone]] and the [[Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia]] consider sexual violence as a public tool of war rather than a private crime.<ref>{{cite book|last=St-Germain|first= Tonia|title=Conflict-related sexual violence : international law, local responses|year=2012|publisher=Kumarian Press|location=Sterling, Va.|isbn=978-1-56549-504-3|pages=53–70|author2=Dewey, Susan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Analytical and Conceptual Framing of Conflict-Related Sexual Violence|url=http://www.stoprapenow.org/uploads/advocacyresources/1321456915.pdf|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref> Groundbreaking [[case law]] both by the ''ad hoc'' Tribunals of [[ICTR]] and [[ICTY]] established unprecedented developments by classifying acts of [[war rape|rape]] and sexual violence as [[Genocide#As a crime|crimes of genocide]] and [[crimes against humanity]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Lindsey|first=Charlotte|title=Women facing war|year=2001|publisher=ICRC|location=Geneva|pages=57–58}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=St-Germain|first= Tonia|title=Conflict-related sexual violence : international law, local responses|year=2012|publisher=Kumarian Press|location=Sterling, Va.|isbn=978-1-56549-504-3|pages=55–57|author2=Dewey, Susan}}</ref>
The [[Akayesu#Trial|Akayesu case]] goes beyond [[domestic law]] definitions of sexual violence and is the first case in which sexual violence is perceived as an integral part of [[genocide]] as defined in the [[Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide|1948 Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide]].<ref name="unictr">{{cite web|title=The Prosecutor v. Jean-Paul Akayesu, Case No. ICTR-96-4-T|url=http://www.unictr.org/Portals/0/Case/English/Akayesu/judgement/akay001.pdf|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=St-Germain|first= Tonia|title=Conflict-related sexual violence : international law, local responses|year=2012|publisher=Kumarian Press|location=Sterling, Va.|isbn=978-1-56549-504-3|page=58|author2=Dewey, Susan}}</ref> On 2 September 1998, the [[International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda]] (ICTR) found [[Jean-Paul Akayesu]] guilty of [[genocide]] and [[crimes against humanity]], and "sexual violence" is cited more than 100 times in the judgment.<ref name="unictr" /> The trial chamber also held that "sexual violence was an integral part of the process of destruction, specifically targeting [[Tutsi]] women and specifically contributing to their destruction and to the destruction of the Tutsi group as a whole".<ref name="unictr" />
The first trial solely focused on the perpetration of systematic sexual violence ([[rape camps]]) and on [[crimes against humanity]] committed against women and girls was in the [[Foča massacres|Foca case]], a ruling before the [[International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY).<ref>{{cite web|title=Case information sheet on the Foca Case (Kunarac, Kovac & Vukovic) (IT-96-23 and 23/1)|url=http://www.icty.org/x/cases/kunarac/cis/en/cis_kunarac_al_en.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Prosecutor v. Dragoljub Kunarac, Radomir Kovac, and Zoran Vukovic, IT-96-23-T& IT-96-23/1-T|url=http://www.icty.org/x/cases/kunarac/tjug/en/kun-tj010222e.pdf}}</ref> The Statute of the [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC) also explicitly incorporates rape and other forms of sexual violence in the list of [[war crimes]] and therefore recognizes sexual violence as a grave breach of [[international humanitarian law]] and of the [[Geneva Conventions]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Statute of the International Criminal Court (Rome Statute)|url=http://www.icc-cpi.int/NR/rdonlyres/EA9AEFF7-5752-4F84-BE94-0A655EB30E16/0/Rome_Statute_English.pdf|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Physicians for Human Rights|title=War-related sexual violence in Sierra Leone : a population-based assessment : a report|year=2002|publisher=Physicians for Human Rights|location=Boston, MA|isbn=1-879707-37-3|page=vi}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Instrument !! Relevant provisions !! Relevant citations or additional information |- | [http://www.icty.org/x/file/Legal%20Library/Statute/statute_sept09_en.pdf Statute of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (1993)] || Article 5 (g)(i) || '''Article 5. Crimes against humanity''' The International Tribunal shall have the power to prosecute persons responsible for the following crimes when committed in armed conflict, whether international or internal in character, and directed against any civilian population (...) (g) rape (...) (i) other inhumane acts. |- | [http://www.unictr.org/Portals/0/English/Legal/Statute/2010.pdf Statute of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (1994)] || Article 3(g)(i) || '''Article 3. Crimes Against Humanity''' The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have the power to prosecute persons responsible for the following crimes when committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack against any civilian population on national, political, ethnic, racial or religious grounds (...) (g) Rape (...) (i) Other inhumane acts (...) |- | [http://www.unictr.org/Portals/0/English/Legal/Statute/2010.pdf Statute of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (1994)] || Article 4(e) || '''Article 4. Violations of Article 3 Common to the Geneva Conventions and of Additional Protocol II''' The International Tribunal for Rwanda shall have the power to prosecute persons committing or ordering to be committed serious violations of Article 3 common to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 for the Protection of War Victims, and of Additional Protocol II thereto of 8 June 1977. These violations shall include, but shall not be limited to (...) (e) Outrages upon personal dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment, rape, enforced prostitution and any form of indecent assault (...) |- | [http://www.icc-cpi.int/NR/rdonlyres/EA9AEFF7-5752-4F84-BE94-0A655EB30E16/0/Rome_Statute_English.pdf Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (1998)] || Article 7(2) (f) || '''Article 7. Crimes against humanity''' (…) Rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution, forced pregnancy (…) enforced sterilization, or any other form of sexual violence of comparable gravity” as crimes against humanity. The Statute defines “forced pregnancy” as the "unlawful confinement of a woman forcibly made pregnant, with the intent of affecting the ethnic composition of any population or carrying out other grave violations of international law”. |- | [http://www.icc-cpi.int/NR/rdonlyres/EA9AEFF7-5752-4F84-BE94-0A655EB30E16/0/Rome_Statute_English.pdf Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (1998)] || Article 8(2) (b) (xxi) (xxii) || '''Article 8. War crimes''' (b) Other serious violations of the laws and customs applicable in international armed conflict, within the established framework of international law, namely, any of the following acts: (...) (xxi) Committing outrages upon personal dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment (xxii) Committing rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution, forced pregnancy, as defined in article 7, paragraph 2 (f), enforced sterilization, or any other form of sexual viol (...) |- | [http://www.icc-cpi.int/NR/rdonlyres/EA9AEFF7-5752-4F84-BE94-0A655EB30E16/0/Rome_Statute_English.pdf Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (1998)] || Article 8(2) (e) (vi) || '''Article 8. War crimes''' (e) Other serious violations of the laws and customs applicable in armed conflicts not of an international character, within the established framework of international law, namely, any of the following acts: (...) (vi) Committing rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution, forced pregnancy, as defined in article 7, paragraph 2 (f), enforced sterilization, and any other form of sexual violence also constituting a serious violation of article 3 common to the four Geneva Conventions (...) |- | [http://www.sc-sl.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=uClnd1MJeEw%3d&tabid=176 Statute of the Special Court for Sierra Leone (2000)] || Article 2(f)(g)(i) || '''Article 2. Crimes Against Humanity''' The Special Court shall have the power to prosecute persons who committed the following crimes as part of a widespread or systematic attack against any civilian population: (...) g. Rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution, forced pregnancy and any other form of sexual violence (...) i. Other inhumane acts. |- |}
== Human rights law, the United Nations, and further developments == {{rquote|right|The continued engagement of the [[Security Council]] must serve as an unequivocal statement of intent: sexual violence in [[Conflict (process)|conflict]] will not be tolerated, and the full force of international order will be brought to bear to ensure accountability for such crimes.The [[perpetrators]] must understand that there can be no hiding place; no [[amnesty]]; no safe harbour. They must know that they will be pursued by any and all means at our collective disposal. In the process, we will begin to transfer the stigma of this crime from the survivors, to the [[perpetrators]].| [[Zainab Hawa Bangura]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Zainab Hawa Bangura|title=Statement by the Special Representative of the Secretary-General on Sexual Violence in Conflict|url=https://www.un.org/sexualviolenceinconflict/statement/statement-by-srsg-zainab-hawa-bangura-to-the-security-council-17-april-2013/|accessdate=28 November 2013|date=April 17, 2013}}</ref>}}
An extensive amount of both [[Hard law|hard]] and [[soft law]] instruments set rules, standards and norms for the protection of victims of sexual offences. Among the wide range of international human rights law instruments are the [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women]] (1979),<ref>{{cite web |title=Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (1979), art. 6 |url=https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/cedaw/text/econvention.htm#article6 |accessdate=29 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xc2eRFDv?url=http://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/cedaw/text/econvention.htm |archivedate=1 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> the [[Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women]] (1993), the Inter-American Convention on the Prevention, Punishment and Eradication of Violence Against Women (1994),<ref>[http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/instree/brazil1994.html Inter-American Convention on the Prevention, Punishment and Eradication of Violence Against Women (1994)]</ref> the [[Protocol to the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights on the Rights of Women in Africa]] (2003), and the [[Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action]] (1993). The [[UN Security Council]], [[ECOSOC]] and the [[UN Commission on Human Rights]] do not take into account the nature of the conflict with respect to the protection of women in war time.<ref name="icrc_a" />
Five UN Security Council Resolutions specifically address sexual violence:
# [http://www.un-documents.net/sr1325.htm UNSC Resolution 1325 (2000)] # [http://www.peacewomen.org/themes_page.php?id=16&subtheme=true&adhoc=90 UNSC Resolution 1820 (2008)] # [http://www.peacewomen.org/assets/file/BasicWPSDocs/scr1888.pdf UNSC Resolution 1888 (2009)] # [http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/WPS%20SRES%201960.pdf UNSC Resolution 1960 (2010)] # [http://peacemaker.un.org/sites/peacemaker.un.org/files/SC_ResolutionWomen_SRES2106(2013)(english).pdf UNSC Resolution 2106 (2013)]
Seven reports from the Secretary-General relate to sexual violence in conflict:
# [http://www.securitycouncilreport.org/atf/cf/%7B65BFCF9B-6D27-4E9C-8CD3-CF6E4FF96FF9%7D/WPS%20S%202010%20604.pdf Report of the SG on the implementation of SC resolutions 1820 and 1888 (2010)] # [https://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N11/650/18/PDF/N1165018.pdf?OpenElement Report of the SG on conflict-related sexual violence (2012)] # [http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/2013/149 Report of the SG on conflict-related sexual violence (2013)] # [http://undocs.org/S/2014/181 Report of the SG on conflict-related sexual violence (2014)] # [http://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/2015/203 Report of the SG on conflict-related sexual violence (2015)] # [http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/2016/361/Rev.1 Report of the SG on conflict-related sexual violence (2016)] # [http://www.undocs.org/S/2017/249 Report of the SG on conflict-related sexual violence (2017)]
The first time the [[Security Council]] addressed the impacts of armed conflict on women was in [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1325|Resolution 1325 (2000)]]. The document focuses on the need for specific protections for women and girls in conflict and expresses the need to consider gender perspectives in mission, UN peace support operations, and post-conflict processes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peace Women. Women, Peac and Security: Resolution 1325|url=http://peacewomen.org/themes_theme.php?id=15&subtheme=true|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref>
[[Resolution 1820|Resolution 1820 (2008)]] of the [[UN Security Council]] declares that [[rape]] and other forms of sexual violence "can constitute [[war crimes]], [[crimes against humanity]] or a constitutive act with respect to [[genocide]]".
[[File:Zainab Bangura giving a radio interview in Kinshasa (8654821769).jpg|thumb|Zainab Bangura, the United Nations Special Representative on Sexual Violence in Conflict since September 2012]] [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1888|Resolution 1888 (2009)]] is perceived as an advancement in international law as it created the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary General for Sexual Violence in Conflict (SRSG-SVC).<ref name="un" /> The first Special Representative, [[Margot Wallström]], was appointed in April 2010. The current Special Representative [[Zainab Hawa Bangura]] took office in September 2012. The Office identified eight priority countries: [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]; [[Central African Republic]] (CAR); [[Colombia]]; [[Cote d’Ivoire]]; [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] (DRC); [[Liberia]]; [[South Sudan]] and [[Sudan]].<ref name="un">{{cite web|title=Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Sexual Violence in Conflict|url=https://www.un.org/sexualviolenceinconflict/about-us/about-the-office/|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref> SRSG-SVC is also engaged in the Middle East ([[Syria]]) and in Asia and the Pacific ([[Cambodia]]).<ref name="un" />
The six priorities of the Office are:
# to end impunity for sexual violence in conflict by assisting national authorities to strengthen criminal accountability, responsiveness to survivors and judicial capacity; # the protection and empowerment of civilians who face sexual violence in conflict, in particular, women and girls who are targeted disproportionately by this crime; # to mobilize political ownership by fostering government engagement in developing and implementing strategies to combat sexual violence; # to increase recognition of rape as a tactic and consequence of war through awareness-raising activities at the international and country levels; # to harmonise the UN’s response by leading [[UN Action Against Sexual Violence in Conflict]], a network of focal points from 13 UN agencies that amplify programming and advocacy on this issue in the wider UN agenda; # to emphasize greater national ownership.<ref name="un" />
[[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1960|Resolution 1960 (2010)]] reaffirms that sexual violence is systematic, rampant and widespread.<ref>{{cite web|title=Security Council Open Debate on Sexual Violence in Conflict, December 2010 (Security Council Resolution 1960)|url=http://www.peacewomen.org/security_council_monitor/debate-watch/all-debates/26/open-debate-on-sexual-violence-in-conflict|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref> The resolution creates new institutional tools for the prevention and protection from sexual violence. The aim of the resolution is to provide further steps for combating impunity and recognizing sexual violence as a serious breach of human rights law and international humanitarian law.<ref>{{cite web|title=Provisional Guidance Note - Implementation of Security Council Resolution 1960 (2010) On Women, Peace and Security (conflict-related sexual violence)|url=http://www.refworld.org/publisher,SRSG_SVC,,,4e23ed5d2,0.html|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref>
Resolution 2106 (2013) reasserts fundamental requirements for the prevention of sexual violence in conflict and post-conflict setting: gender equality, women empowerment, and the importance of implementing the full range of commitments found in resolution 1325.<ref>{{cite web|title=UN Women welcomes the unanimous adoption of Security Council resolution 2106 on conflict-related sexual violence|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2013/6/un-women-welcomes-the-unanimous-adoption-of-security-council-resolution-2106/|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Security Council Open Debate on Sexual Violence in Conflict, June 2013 (Security Council Resolution 2106)|url=http://www.peacewomen.org/security_council_monitor/debate-watch/all-debates/62/security-council-open-debate-on-sexual-violence-in-conflict|accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref>

{{SCICase |Litigants= Justice K. S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) and Anr. vs Union Of India And Ors. |DecideDate=24 August |DecideYear=2017 |FullName= Justice K. S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) and Anr. vs Union Of India And Ors. |Citation= WRIT PETITION (CIVIL) NO 494 OF 2012 |Holding= The right to privacy is protected under Articles 14, 19 and 21 of the [[Constitution of India|Constitution]]. |CaseOpinion= [[Dhananjaya Y. Chandrachud|D Y Chandrachud]], J. |LawsApplied= }}
'''''Justice K. S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) and Anr. vs Union Of India And Ors''' .''is a landmark judgment of the [[Supreme Court of India]], which holds that the right to privacy is protected as a fundamental constitutional right under Articles 14, 19 and 21 of the [[Constitution of India]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bhandari|first=Vrinda|last2=Kak|first2=Amba|last3=Parsheera|first3=Smriti|last4=Rahman|first4=Faiza|date=|title=An Analysis of Puttaswamy: The Supreme Court's Privacy Verdict|url=http://www.indrastra.com/2017/11/An-Analysis-of-Puttaswamy-Supreme-Court-s-Privacy-Verdict-003-11-2017-0004.html|journal=IndraStra Global|volume=003|pages=004|issn=2381-3652|via=}}</ref>
The judgement of the nine-judge [[Constitution bench (India)|constitution bench]] contains six concurring opinions affirming the right to privacy of Indian citizens. It explicitly overrules previous judgements of the Supreme Court in ''Kharak Singh vs. State of UP'' and ''M.P Sharma v Union of India'', which had held that there is no fundamental right to privacy under the Indian Constitution.
The judgment was interpreted as paving the way for the eventual decriminalisation of homosexuality in India in ''[[Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India]]'' (2018).

{{infobox Website | name = Legal Information Institute (LII) | logo = | screenshot = [[File:Legal Information Institute Screenshot.jpg|border|300px|alt=LII's Homepage.|The home page of LII on 03/03/2010]] | caption = The home page of LII on 03/03/2010 | url = [http://law.cornell.edu/ law.cornell.edu] | type = [[Nonprofit]], [[Free access to law movement|Open Access]] to [[Law of the United States|US Law]] | language = English, some French<ref>[http://topics.law.cornell.edu/wex/francis Wex:Espanol]</ref> | registration = Optional | owner = [[Cornell Law School]] | launch date = {{Start date and years ago|mf=yes|1992|1|1}} | commercial = No | current status = Available | author = [[Peter W. Martin (professor)|Peter Martin]] and [[Thomas R. Bruce|Tom Bruce]] }}
The '''Legal Information Institute''' ('''LII''') is a [[non-profit]], public service of [[Cornell Law School]] that provides no-cost access to current [[American law|American]] and [[international law|international]] [[legal research]] sources online at [http://law.cornell.edu law.cornell.edu]. The organization is a pioneer in the delivery of legal information online.<ref name="Laurence"/> Founded in 1992 by [[Peter Martin (Law Professor)|Peter Martin]] and [[Thomas R. Bruce|Tom Bruce]],<ref name='Amant'>{{cite book | last = St. Amant| first = Kirk | title = Handbook of Research on Open Source Software: Technological, Economic, and Social Perspectives | publisher = IGI Global | year = 2007| pages = 375 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=75KT6GdcWbYC&pg=PA375 | isbn = 1-59140-999-3}}</ref><ref name='Stefanou'>{{cite book | last = Stefanou | first = Constantin |author2=Helen Xanthaki | title = Drafting legislation: a modern approach | publisher = Ashgate Publishing | year = 2008| pages = 272 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=xMyItDp8TIwC&pg=PA272 | isbn = 0-7546-4903-2}}</ref> LII was the first law site developed on the internet.<ref name='Laurence'>{{cite book | last = Laurence | first = Helen |author2=William Miller | title = Academic research on the Internet: options for scholars and libraries | publisher = Routledge | year = 2000 | pages = 160 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=U3DTGfZkHywC&lpg=PA160&dq=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20%22cornell%22&pg=PA160#v=onepage&q=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20%22cornell%22 | isbn = 0-7890-1177-8}}</ref> LII electronically publishes on the Web the [[U.S. Code]], [[U.S. Supreme Court]] [[Case law|opinions]], [[Uniform Commercial Code]], the US [[Code of Federal Regulations]], several Federal Rules,<ref name='Hart'>{{cite book | last = Hart | first = William |author2=Roderick D. Blanchard | title = Litigation and Trial Practice | publisher = Delmar Cengage Learning | date = July 18, 2006 | pages = 160 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=P4ojyCvMbKoC&pg=PA24&dq=%22legal+information+institute%22+federal+rules&cd=25#v=onepage&q=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20federal%20rules | edition = 6th | isbn = 1-4180-1689-6}}</ref> and a variety of other [[American law|American]] [[primary authority|primary law]] materials.<ref name= Myers>{{Cite web | last = Myers | first = Linda, [[Cornell University]] ''Chronicle'' (04/20/00) | title =CU Law Institute Web Site has Latest Legal Information | url=http://www.news.cornell.edu/Chronicle/00/4.27.00/Legal_Info_Inst.html |accessdate = 2008-06-10 <!--None-->}}.</ref> LII also provides access to other [[Nation state|national]] and [[international law|international]] sources, such as [[treaties]] and [[United Nations]] materials.<ref name='Herman'>{{cite book | last = Herman | first = Edward | title = Locating United States Government Information: A Guide to Sources, 2001 Internet Supplement | publisher = William S Hein & Co | year = 2001 | pages = 27 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=CWtiUHqm1PAC&pg=PA114&dq=cornell+%22legal+information+institute%22&cd=2#v=onepage&q=cornell%20%22legal%20information%20institute%22 | isbn = 1-57588-683-9}}</ref> According to its website, the LII serves over 30 million [[unique visitor]]s per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/lii/about/about_lii|title=About the LII|work=Legal Information Institute}}</ref>
Since its inception, the Legal Information Institute has inspired others around the world to develop namesake operations.<ref name= Myers/> These services are part of the [[Free Access to Law Movement]].
==History== LII was established in 1992 at Cornell Law School by [[Peter Martin (Law Professor)|Professor Peter Martin]] and [[Thomas R. Bruce|Tom Bruce]] with a $250,000 multi-year startup grant from the National Center for Automated Information Research.<ref name=LIIOverview>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/lii.html |title= LII:Overview |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref> The LII was originally based on [[Gopher (protocol)|Gopher]] and provided access to [[United States Supreme Court]] decisions and the [[United States Code|US Code]].<ref name="Amant"/> Its original mission included the intent to "carry out applied research on the use of digital information technology in the distribution of legal information,...[and t]o make law more accessible."<ref name= LIIOverview/> In the early years of LII, Bruce developed [[Cello (web browser)|Cello]] the first [[web browser]] for [[Microsoft Windows]].<ref name= celloref>{{Cite web | title = The World Wide Web History Project - Web History Day: Pioneering Software and Sites | url=http://1997.webhistory.org/historyday/abstracts.html#tom |accessdate = 2010-03-04 <!--None-->}}</ref><ref name='He'>{{cite book | last = He | first = Jimin | title = Internet resources for engineers | publisher = Elsevier | year = 1998 | pages = 34 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=T6F9GSJOgzoC&pg=PA34&dq=tom+bruce+cello&cd=1#v=onepage&q= | isbn = 978-0-7506-8949-6 }}</ref> Cello was released on 8 June 1993.<ref name='Gillies'>{{cite book | last = Gillies | first = James |author2=Cailliau, R. | title = How the Web was born: the story of the World Wide Web | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | year = 2000 | pages = 235 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=pIH-JijUNS0C&pg=PA235&dq=tom+bruce+cello&cd=3#v=onepage&q=tom%20bruce%20cello | isbn = 978-0-19-286207-5 }}</ref> In 1994 LII moved from [[Gopher (protocol)|Gopher]] to the [[World Wide Web|Web]].<ref name="Amant"/> Since 2007 the [[IRS]] has distributed its IRS Tax Products DVD<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntis.gov/products/irsdvd.aspx/ | title= IRS DVD Link | accessdate = 2010-03-04}}</ref> with LII's version of [[Internal Revenue Code|26 USC (Internal Revenue Code)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.law.cornell.edu/blog/2010/01/06/nothing-sure-but/ |title= LII Announce: Nothing sure but... |accessdate=2010-03-04}}</ref>
==LII Supreme Court Collection and LII Bulletin== LII has an extensive collection of law from the [[Supreme Court of the United States]].<ref name='Trinkle'>{{cite book | last = Trinkle| first = Dennis A. |author2=Scott A. Merriman | title = The History Highway: A 21st-Century Guide to Internet Resources | publisher = M.E. Sharpe | year = 2001 | pages = 338 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=unxWZysEnWsC&pg=PA338&dq=%22legal+information+institute%22+and+%22cornell%22&cd=22#v=onepage&q=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20and%20%22cornell%22 | isbn = 0-7656-1630-0}}</ref> It hosts all Supreme Court decisions since 1990 and over 600 historic Supreme Court pre-1992 decisions in web form ([https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/cases/topic.htm/ by party name], [https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/cases/author.htm by authoring justice], and [https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/cases/topic.htm by topic]).<ref name='Hall'>{{cite book | last = Hall | first = Kermit |author2=John J. Patrick | title = The pursuit of justice: Supreme Court decisions that shaped America | publisher = Oxford University Press US | year = 2006 | pages = 244 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=4upmi30oV8cC&lpg=PA247&dq=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20and%20%22cornell%22&pg=PA247#v=onepage&q=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20and%20%22cornell%22 | isbn = 0-19-532568-0}}</ref>
The [https://www.law.cornell.edu/bulletin/ LII Supreme Court Bulletin] is LII's free Supreme Court email-based subscriber and web-based publication service.<ref name= Crawford>{{Cite web | last = Crawford | first = Franklin [[Cornell University]] ''Chronicle'' (09/17/2007) | title =Cornell Legal Information Institute posts previews of Supreme Court cases | url=http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Sept07/Law.LII.Preview.html |accessdate = 2010-03-04 <!--None-->}}.</ref> The Bulletin provides subscribers with two distinct services.<ref name=Bruce>{{Cite web | last = Bruce | first = Tom, B-Screeds (03/03/09) | title =The LIIBULLETIN: believe it or not | url=http://blog.law.cornell.edu/tbruce/2009/03/30/the-liibulletin-believe-it-or-not/ |accessdate = 2010-03-03 <!--None-->}}.</ref> The first is a notification service. LII Bulletin emails subscribers with timely notification of when the US Supreme Court has handed down a decision.<ref name='Ambrogi'>{{cite book | last = Ambrogi | first = Robert | title = The essential guide to the best (and worst) legal sites on the Web | publisher = ALM Publishing | year = 2004| pages = 333 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Y4oETB8_EbIC&lpg=PA154&dq=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20%22cornell%22&pg=PA333#v=onepage&q=%22legal%20information%20institute%22%20%22cornell%22 | isbn = 1-58852-117-6}}</ref> It also provides subscribers links to the full opinions of those cases on the LII site.<ref name="Ambrogi"/>
The second service of LII Bulletin is a preview and analysis service for upcoming Supreme Court cases. Subscribers to the Bulletin receive legal analysis of upcoming Supreme Court cases with the intention of providing sophisticated yet accessible previews of the cases.<ref name= Bruce/> LII selectively recruits second- and third-year students of the [[Cornell Law School]] to comprise the LII Bulletin editorial board.<ref name= Bruce/> The Bulletin editorial board is responsible for every aspect of the journal's management, from selecting decisions for commentary to researching, writing, editing, and producing the journal content in HTML.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://topics.law.cornell.edu/supct/cert |title=liibulletin: The LII Supreme Court Bulletin |accessdate=2010-03-03}}</ref>
==Wex Legal Dictionary and Encyclopedia== LII publishes a [[wiki]] called the ''Wex Legal Dictionary/Encyclopedia''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://topics.law.cornell.edu/wex/|title=Wex|work=Legal Information Institute}}</ref> As a wiki, it is a collaboratively authored, freely available legal reference. Qualified legal experts are allowed to post and edit entries on legal topics within Wex.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://topics.law.cornell.edu/wex/editorial_contributions |title=liibulletin: Editorial Contributions |accessdate=2010-03-03}}</ref>
==Similar institutions== *[[Free Access to Law Movement]] unites many similar institutions, including **[[AfricanLII]] **[[AustLII]] **[[BAILII]] **[[CanLII]] **[[HKLII]] **[[NZLII]] **[[PacLII]] **[[SAFLII]] **[[WorldLII]]
==See also== * [[Legal awareness]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.law.cornell.edu/}}
{{Cornell}}

{{Infobox referendum | name = Question 5: Citizen Initiative | title = '''An Act To Establish Ranked-Choice Voting''' | yes = 388273 | no = 356621 | total = 771708 | electorate = 1058444 | map = | mapdivision = | notes = Source: [[Maine Secretary of State]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/results/results16-17.html#tally |title=November 8, 2016 General Election |publisher=Maine Department of Secretary of State}}</ref> }}
{{ElectionsME}} '''Maine Question 5''', formally '''An Act to Establish Ranked-Choice Voting''',<ref>https://www1.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/upcoming/citizensguide2016.pdf</ref> is a citizen-initiated referendum question that qualified for the [[Maine]] November 8, 2016 statewide ballot and was approved by a margin of 52% to 48%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/maine-ballot-measure-5-allow-ranked-choice-voting |title=Maine Question 5 — Allow Ranked-Choice Voting — Results: Approved – Election Results 2016 |publisher=New York Times |date=2017-08-01 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> It would change how most Maine elections will be conducted from a [[plurality voting system]] to a [[Instant-runoff voting|ranked choice voting]] system (RCV, also known as instant runoff voting). It appeared on the ballot along with elections for [[United States presidential election, 2016|President of the United States]], [[United States House of Representatives elections in Maine, 2016|Maine's two U.S. House seats]], the Legislature, [[Maine referendums, 2016|five other ballot questions]], and various local elections. Maine would be the first state to use such a system for its statewide elections for governor and U.S. Senate if implemented.
An [[advisory opinion]] by the [[Maine Supreme Judicial Court]], issued on May 23, 2017, stated that the Court would rule ranked choice voting unconstitutional if it came before them, with respect to elections for state offices. This led the [[Maine Legislature]] to vote to delay its implementation until 2021 to allow time for a Constitutional amendment to be passed to permit it. Supporters gathered signatures to force a successful [[people's veto]] [[Maine Question 1, June 2018|referendum]] on the matter in order to prevent the delay.
==Background== In the 11 Maine gubernatorial elections prior to 2016, only incumbent Governors [[Joseph E. Brennan|Joe Brennan]] in [[Maine gubernatorial election, 1982|1982]] and [[Angus King]] in [[Maine gubernatorial election, 1998|1998]] won more than 50% of the vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2015/10/12/politics/maine-group-launching-campaign-for-ranked-choice-voting/?ref=relatedBox|title=Maine group launching campaign for ranked-choice voting|publisher=Bangor Daily News/Lewiston SunJournal |date=October 12, 2015 |accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref> Typically gubernatorial elections have more than two candidates; the [[Maine gubernatorial election, 2010|2010 election]] had five candidates, with [[Paul LePage]] emerging as the winner with 37.6% of the vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maine.gov/sos/cec/elec/results/2010-11/gen2010gov.html|title=2010 Governor General Election Tabulations|publisher=Office of the Maine Secretary of State |accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref> Some public opinion felt that his victory was due to opponents of LePage dividing their votes between Democratic candidate [[Libby Mitchell]] and independent candidate [[Eliot Cutler]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/10/27/politics/elections/maine-lawmakers-seek-to-end-strategic-voting-spoilers-with-petition-for-ranked-choice-voting/?ref=relatedBox|title=Maine lawmakers seek to end strategic voting, ‘spoilers’ with petition for ranked-choice voting|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=October 27, 2015 |accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref>
Proposals to enact ranked choice voting have been introduced in the Legislature as early as 2003, but were rejected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.bangordailynews.com/2003/02/20/bill-seeks-to-assure-majority-vote-wins|title=Bill seeks to assure majority vote wins|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=February 20, 2003 |accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2011/03/14/opinion/a-better-way-to-vote-2/?ref=relatedBox|title=A Better Way to Vote|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=March 14, 2011 |accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref> After a 2010 charter change, the city of [[Portland, Maine|Portland]] began electing its mayor using ranked choice voting in [[Portland, Maine mayoral election, 2011|2011]]. There were new legislative proposals in 2011, though they were rejected as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/05/06/politics/state-house/bill-to-create-maine-presidential-primary-adopt-ranked-choice-voting-comes-with-hefty-price-tag/?ref=relatedBox|title=Bill to create Maine presidential primary, adopt ranked-choice voting comes with hefty price tag|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=May 6, 2013 |accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref> In 2014, upon releasing his supporters to vote for someone else in the [[Maine gubernatorial election, 2014|2014 election]], Eliot Cutler encouraged his supporters to support ranked choice voting.<ref name=cutler>{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/10/29/politics/cutler-to-make-election-announcement-at-impromptu-news-conference-wednesday-morning/|title=Cutler says victory is ‘long shot,’ tells supporters to vote accordingly|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=October 29, 2014 |accessdate=October 29, 2014}}</ref> Led by former independent [[Maine Senate|State Senator]] [[Richard Woodbury|Dick Woodbury]], Ranked Choice Voting collected more than the 61,123 valid signatures necessary to put a proposal to voters, collecting some 40,000 on Election Day 2014. The group collected 75,369 signatures and delivered them to [[Maine Secretary of State]] [[Matthew Dunlap]] by October 19, 2015. Dunlap ultimately certified 64,687 signatures by November 18, 2015, which put the proposal on the November 2016 ballot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maine.gov/sos/news/2015/rankedchoiceinitiative.html|title=Citizens’ initiative for ranked-choice voting found valid with 64,687 signatures|publisher=Office of the Maine Secretary of State |date=November 18, 2015 |accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref>
Per the Maine Constitution, the proposal went to the Legislature in its 2016 session, but it did not act on the measure. On January 20, 2016, the [[Maine House of Representatives]] voted to place the proposal on the ballot without holding a public hearing, over the objections of Republicans, led by Rep. Heather Sirocki, expressing concern about the constitutionality of the proposal.<ref name=constitution /> Secretary of State Dunlap released the final wording of the question on June 23 as it will appear on the ballot: "Do you want to allow voters to rank their choices of candidates in elections for U.S. Senate, Congress, Governor, State Senate, and State Representative, and to have ballots counted at the state level in multiple rounds in which last-place candidates are eliminated until a candidate wins by majority?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stateandcapitol.bangordailynews.com/2016/06/23/maine-secretary-of-state-revises-wording-of-all-five-november-ballot-questions/|title=Maine secretary of state revises wording of all five November ballot questions|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=June 23, 2016 |accessdate=June 23, 2016}}</ref>
===Constitutionality=== Some, including a Deputy Secretary of State and a state legislator, expressed concern about the constitutionality of the proposal. Deputy Secretary of State Julie Flynn said that the Maine Constitution requires that the Governor and state legislators be elected with a plurality of votes and that a system based on ranked choice voting could be challenged in court. (The state constitution was amended in 1847, 1875, and 1880 to choose winners by [[Plurality voting|plurality]] for House, Senate, and Governor, respectively.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rcvmaine.com/history|title=Maine's History of Majority Rule and the Adoption of Plurality Provisions|work=The Committee for Ranked Choice Voting|access-date=2018-01-03}}</ref> Previously, an election with no [[majority]] winner would be decided by multiple election rounds or by the state legislature.)
Flynn also expressed concern that the proposal inserts the Secretary of State into the process, while the Constitution states that votes shall be tabulated by municipal officials.<ref name="constitution">{{cite web|url=http://www.centralmaine.com/2016/01/20/maine-election-official-lawmakers-question-legality-of-ranked-choice-voting-proposal/|title=Maine officials, legislators question legality of ranked-choice voting|publisher=Kennebec Journal |date=January 21, 2016 |accessdate=January 21, 2016}}</ref> [[Maine Attorney General]] [[Janet T. Mills|Janet Mills]] issued an opinion at the request of [[Maine Senate]] President [[Michael Thibodeau]] stating that while the referendum must appear on the ballot, it will likely require amending the Maine Constitution to implement it, in order to satisfy the concerns given by the Secretary of State's office.
She added that the manner in which the proposal addresses how a tie in the voting should be addressed, drawing lots, directly conflicted with Article V of the Maine Constitution, which states that a tie in the vote for Governor would be settled by the Maine Legislature meeting in joint session to choose a winner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/03/05/maine-attorney-general-says-ranked-choice-voting-may-require-amending-constitution/|title=Maine attorney general says ranked-choice voting may require amending constitution|publisher=Portland Press Herald |date=March 5, 2016 |accessdate=March 7, 2016}}</ref>
The Committee for Ranked Choice Voting Maine dismissed such concerns, noting that a majority vote is always a plurality vote and that such a system has survived legal challenges in several other states. Its website statement also linked to statements by several Maine law professors supporting its arguments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rcvmaine.com/does_ranked_choice_voting_raise_any_constitutional_questions|title=Does ranked choice voting raise any constitutional questions?|publisher=Committee for Ranked Choice Voting|accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref>
After the question was approved by voters, the Maine Senate submitted questions to the Maine Supreme Judicial Court, which issued an advisory opinion on May 23, 2017. They unanimously ruled that ranked choice voting was unconstitutional in state, but not federal, general elections. In response, the legislature passed a law on November 4, 2017 that amended the ranked-choice voting law to apply only to primary elections for Congress, Governor, State Senator, and State Representative; and for general elections for Congress.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ranked Choice Voting in Maine |url=http://legislature.maine.gov/lawlibrary/ranked-choice-voting-in-maine/9509 |accessdate=14 November 2018}}</ref>
==Campaign== Supporters of the proposal, led by Ranked Choice Voting Maine, contend that it will lead to people voting for the candidate that they support and end strategic voting to vote merely for the candidate that they think will win, and that the ranked choice system will result in a candidate that has some level of support from a majority of voters. They further contend that ranked choice voting will result in less negative campaigning, as candidates will need to appeal to a broad coalition of voters beyond their base of supporters to gain support as a second or third choice, if needed.

Grover, former [[Cumberland County, Maine|Cumberland County]] Commissioner<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cumberlandcounty.org/489/History-of-Cumberland-County-Commissione |title=History of Cumberland County Commissioners |publisher=Cumberland County |date= |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> (2013-2014)<ref>{{cite web|last=Grover |first=Mark D. |url=http://news.keepmecurrent.com/the-center-road-democracys-past-present-future |title=The Center Road: Democracy’s past, present, future |publisher=Keep Me Current |date=2015-05-18 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> *[[David Lemoine]], former [[Maine State Treasurer]]<ref name=rcvendorse /> *[[Chellie Pingree]], U.S. Representative<ref name=rcvendorse /> }} {{Endorsements box | title = Media | list = *[[MaineToday Media]] newspapers; ''[[Portland Press Herald]]'', ''[[Morning Sentinel]]'', ''[[Kennebec Journal]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/10/16/our-view-ranked-choice-voting-is-right-choice-for-maine/|title=Our View: Ranked-choice voting is right for Maine|date=October 16, 2016}}</ref> *Brunswick ''[[The Times Record (Maine)|Times-Record]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesrecord.com/news/2014-11-13/Editorial/Ranked_Choice.html |title=Ranked Choice |publisher=The Times Record |date=2014-11-13 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> }}
==== Opponents ==== *[[William Diamond|Bill Diamond]], Democratic State Senator, former [[Secretary of State of Maine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/10/23/question-5-advocates-try-to-allay-confusion/ |title=Question 5 advocates try to allay confusion about ranked-choice voting |publisher=Portland Press Herald |date=2016-10-23 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> *[[Paul LePage]], [[Governor of Maine]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.centralmaine.com/2016/06/22/lepage-action-on-shootings-should-take-mental-illness-into-consideration | title=LePage: Action on shootings should take mental illness into consideration|publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=June 22, 2016|accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref> *Heather Sirocki, State Representative (R-[[Scarborough, Maine|Scarborough]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themainewire.com/2016/03/ranked-choice-voting-wrong-maine-blatantly-unconstitutional| title=Ranked Choice Voting: Wrong for Maine & Blatantly Unconstitutional|publisher=Maine Wire |date=March 29, 2016 |accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref> *''Ellsworth American''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ellsworthamerican.com/opinions/ranked-choice-voting/ |title=Ranked-choice voting |publisher=The Ellsworth American |date=2016-09-16 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> *''[[Bangor Daily News]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2016/10/19/opinion/editorials/the-reasons-for-maine-to-adopt-ranked-choice-voting-are-unconvincing/?goal=0_715eed3192-2180de1cc7-82420600 |title=The reasons for Maine to adopt ranked-choice voting are unconvincing |publisher=Bangor Daily News |date=2016-10-19 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref>
===Polling=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:825px;" |- !Date of opinion poll !Conducted by ![[Sample size]]<br />(likely voters) !Yes !No !Undecided !Margin of Error |- | '''October 20–25, 2016'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/10/31/margins-of-support-shrink-for-3-of-the-6-maine-ballot-issues-poll-indicates/ |title=Leads shrink for 4 of the 6 Maine ballot issues, poll indicates |publisher=Portland Press Herald |date=2016-10-31 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> | University of New Hampshire | 761 | '''49%''' | 31% | 20% | ±3.6% |- | '''September 15–20, 2016'''<ref>{{cite web|author=Scott Thistle |url=http://www.centralmaine.com/2016/09/29/poll-suggests-mainers-open-to-changing-the-way-they-vote/ |title=Poll suggests Mainers open to changing the way they vote |publisher=CentralMaine.com |date=2016-09-29 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref> | University of New Hampshire | 506 | '''48%''' | 29% | 23% | ±4.3% |}
==Maine Supreme Court ruling== On February 3, 2017, the [[Maine Senate]] voted 24-10 to ask the [[Maine Supreme Judicial Court]] for an [[advisory opinion]] as to the constitutionality of the approved proposal, after concerns about its constitutionality were expressed by [[Maine Attorney General]] [[Janet T. Mills|Janet Mills]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainepublic.org/post/maine-senate-asks-high-court-opinion-voter-approved-ranked-choice-initiative#stream/0|title=Maine Senate Asks High Court for Opinion on Voter-Approved Ranked-Choice Initiative |publisher=[[MPBN]]|accessdate=February 3, 2017}}</ref>
On May 23, 2017, the Court issued its opinion that the law would be unconstitutional if it came before them, stating it would violate the provision of the Maine Constitution requiring elections to be decided by a plurality of the vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3728801-Maine-Supreme-Judicial-Court-ruling-on-Ranked.html |title=Opinion of the Justices of the Supreme Judicial Court |date=23 May 2017}}</ref> State legislators had mixed reactions to the ruling, with Senate President [[Michael Thibodeau]] calling for the law to be repealed and Democratic State Sen. Catherine Breen stating she would propose a Constitutional amendment to permit the law.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2017/05/23/politics/maine-supreme-judicial-court-rules-ranked-choice-voting-unconstitutional/|title=Maine Supreme Judicial Court rules ranked-choice voting unconstitutional|last=|first=|date=May 23, 2017|newspaper=Bangor Daily News|accessdate=May 23, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The legislature’s Veterans and Legal Affairs Committee on June 8 reported out to the floor five bills in reaction to the ruling, including one that would implement ranked choice voting in 2018 for uses unaffected by the Court's opinion - that is, congressional elections and primaries.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ranked-choice voting bills go to full Legislature for debate|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2017/06/08/rank-choiced-voting-bills-head-to-full-legislature-for-debate/|accessdate=June 9, 2017|newspaper=Portland Press Herald|date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> On October 23, 2017, the Legislature voted to delay implementation of the RCV law for all races until 2021, to allow for time to pass a state constitutional amendment to allow it. This repeal affects even those races not affected by the Court’s opinion, with the argument that Maine voters would be confused by a mix of RCV and non-RCV choices on a ballot. However, if such an amendment is not passed, the law would be repealed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcsh6.com/news/politics/loose-ends-bring-legislature-back-for-special-session/485282422 |title=Ranked choice voting delayed until 2021 |publisher=WCSH6.com |date=2017-10-23 |accessdate=2017-12-20}}</ref>
===People's veto=== {{also|Maine Question 1, June 2018}}
Supporters, angered by the delay, launched a [[people's veto]] signature-gathering effort to prevent it, pointing to its successful use in mixed-race ballots in Portland. The veto passed as [[Maine Question 1, June 2018]], restoring ranked-choice voting for primary and federal elections.

'''Mook''' is the graffiti [[moniker]] used by an American man '''Michael Monack''', who was active in doing illegal graffiti in [[Pittsburgh]] in the early [[2000s (decade)|2000s]], and subsequently in the late 2010s by a Portland Oregon man '''Marcus Edward Gunther'''. The name means "knucklehead or idiot."<ref name=mcnulty />
{{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = Views of Mook's work | width = 200
| image1 = 10th Street Bridge Mook.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = Close-up on "Mook" tag on [[South Tenth Street Bridge]]
| image2 = Pittsburgh Tenth Street Bridge from Bluff downsteam.JPG | alt2 = | caption2 = view of bridgework Monack vandalized }}
=Michael Monack= Monack began as a tagger targeting the [[South Side (Pittsburgh)|South Side]] and [[Shadyside (Pittsburgh)|Shadyside]] neighborhoods, but after his tags were abated, he began placing his tags in hard to reach places, including tall bridges and highway overpasses.<ref name=mcnulty>{{cite news | last =McNulty | first =Timothy | title = Police anger reaches new heights over Mook's daredevil graffiti | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date =October 5, 2001 | url =http://old.post-gazette.com/regionstate/20011005graffiti1005p3.asp | archiveurl= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iOhRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fnADAAAAIBAJ&pg=1587%2C1492297 | archivedate=October 5, 2001| accessdate = }}</ref> He drew the ire of the then-[[Pittsburgh Mayor]] [[Thomas J. Murphy, Jr.]], who had tried to provide an outlet for individuals interested in graffiti to use the walls along the [[Three Rivers Heritage Trail|Eliza Furnace trail]].<ref name=mcnulty /> He has etched "Mook" onto a Department of Public Works "Graffiti Busters" truck that was tasked with cleaning up graffiti.<ref name=mcnulty /> At one point, merchants from the [[South Side (Pittsburgh)|South Side]], tired of having their businesses targeted confronted Monack. He tagged "So you want to get tough?" on the [[Birmingham Bridge]].<ref name=mcnulty /> in response.
He became known around the community for vandalizing previously unheard of places.<ref name=mcnulty /> According to Pittsburgh officials, "He's going into areas no one's gone before."<ref name=mcnulty /> He became known among law enforcement across [[Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite news | last =White | first =Bill | title =Graffiti punks in high places spur curiosity | newspaper =[[The Morning Call]] | date =Aug 7, 2004 | url =https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/mcall/doc/393118774.html | accessdate = }}</ref> After the media coverage of Monack's "Mook" tagging in the Pittsburgh area, it is possible that multiple copycats have applied graffiti using the moniker "Mook".<ref name=mcnulty /> As Monack received more coverage for his daredevil mischief, he gained more opponents as well as supporters.<ref>{{cite news | last =Andrews | first =Al | title =The Mook Case Is Being Mishandled By Local Officials | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date =October 12, 2001 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_IVIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gHADAAAAIBAJ&pg=4968,407381 | accessdate = }}</ref> One of his supporters described him as "determined and skilled and has a sense of humor," commenting that "Although Mook has committed a crime, everyone loves him and he makes people happy."<ref>{{cite news | last =Silverman | first =Auora | title ="Mook" Makes Us Happy | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date =November 7, 2001 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TfFRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gXADAAAAIBAJ&pg=3651,4031760 | accessdate = }}</ref> Others objected to the public praise and commented his supporters should help clean up his graffiti.<ref>{{cite news | last =Snedden| first =Kenneth | title =Those Who Glorify "Mook" Should Help to Clean Up His Messes | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date =November 10, 2001 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UPFRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gXADAAAAIBAJ&pg=4716,5444198 | accessdate = }}</ref>
On November 1, 2001, after receiving anonymous tip letters, police arrested 18-year-old [[South Side (Pittsburgh)|South Side]] resident Michael Monack.<ref name="arrest">{{cite news | title =Man Arrested in "Mook" Graffiti Spree | newspaper =[[Beaver County Times]] | date =November 1, 2001 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vsYiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nrYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5191,441727 | accessdate = }}</ref> He was found with graffiti supplies.<ref name="arrest" /> In October 2002, Monack was sentenced to thousands of dollars in fines and community service in exchange for his guilty plea to criminal mischief and defiant trespass.<ref name="norman">{{cite news | last =Norman | first =Tony | title = Painted as a menace, graffiti artist 'Mook' is held for trial | newspaper= [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date =March 13, 2003 | url =http://old.post-gazette.com/columnists/20030313tonyp2.asp | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="byrne" /> On March 2003, police arrested Monack again for continuing to engage in graffiti.<ref name="noted">{{cite news | title =City police arrest noted graffiti writer 'Mook' | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date =March 3, 2003 | url =http://old.post-gazette.com/neigh_city/20030303cmook0303p6.asp | accessdate = }}</ref> Monack had been spotted in the [[Armstrong Tunnel]] at 5AM with two juvenile delinquents. He attempted to escape apprehension and fled to the [[South Tenth Street Bridge|South Tenth Street Bridg]]<nowiki/>e where he was arrested. Monack was charged with criminal mischief, conspiracy, possessing an instrument of a crime and corruption of a minor for being the group's "ringleader."<ref name="noted" /> His hearings were attended by neighborhood activists from areas targeted by his tagging where they expressed their extreme displeasure at his behavior.<ref>{{cite news | last =Norman | first =Tony | title = Will jailing of graffiti artist open a big can of paint? | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date =March 14, 2003 | url =http://old.post-gazette.com/columnists/20030314tony107col2p2.asp | accessdate = }}</ref>
As of 2004, Monack had become a [[tattoo artist]] in Pittsburgh.<ref name="byrne">{{cite news | last =Reilly | first =Richard Byrne | title =Local Graffiti Legend Doesn't Miss Tagging | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]] | date =November 14, 2004 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> When asked by the ''[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]'' about his opinion on the latest crop of the city's graffiti artists, he described them as "garbage."<ref name="byrne" /> Though, even years after ceasing his tagging, Mook's "infamy precedes him in many circles of the city."<ref name="byrne" /> However, his reputation as a graffiti artist in the city has been eclipsed by now deceased Daniel Montano whose moniker is [[MFONE]]<ref>{{cite news | last =Norman | first =Tony | title =Daniel Montano, artist on the run | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]| date =January 29, 2008 | url =http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/opinion/tony-norman/daniel-montano-artist-on-the-run-378126/ | accessdate =September 22, 2013 }}</ref> eMook "made his reputation scaling bridge suspensions and highway underpasses to spray "Mook" in places where even angels fear to tread."|source = Tony Norman, columnist for ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''<ref name=norman />
=Marcus Gunther= [[Oregon Department of Transportation]] and the [[Portland Police Bureau]] began investigating after graffiti appeared on two sets of brand new electronic signs hanging over I-84 freeway in [[Portland, Oregon]] before they have even been commissioned. One of the sets was tagged with the moniker "Mook" on June 29th, 2018. On September 13th, 2018, a Portland man Marcus E Gunther was arrested and charged with a felony criminal mischief and three counts of misdemeanor criminal mischief. He was also accused of a probation violation.<ref>{{cite web |title=Officers Arrest Tagger Thursday Afternoon (Photo) |url=https://www.portlandoregon.gov/police/news/read.cfm?id=189344 |website=Portland Police Public Information |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> He remains in custody in Multnomah County Inverness Jail as of November 28th, 2018 for these charges as well as other unresolved matters. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://mcso.us/PAID/Home/Booking/1447437 |website=Multnomah County Sheriff's Office}}</ref> The damage was nearly $25,000. He was linked back after being caught on video in a separate "Mook" graffiti incident on September 6, 2018 at a storage unit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://katu.com/news/local/police-arrest-man-marcus-gunther-suspected-of-tagging-i-84-freeway-signs|title=Police arrest man suspected of tagging I-84 freeway signs|last=News|first=KATU|work=KATU|access-date=2018-09-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Gunther has prior convictions including unlawful possession of heroin and [[DWI]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/406317-304585-police-graffiti-tagger-inflicted-24000-in-property-damage|title=police graffiti tagger inflicted $24000 in property damage|last=News|first=Portland Tribune|work=Portland Tribune|access-date=2018-09-18}}</ref> [[The Columbian]] reports that Gunther's graffiti tag has been found in [[Vancouver, Washington]] as well.<ref>{{cite news |title=Portland police arrest man allegedly responsible for ‘MOOK’ graffiti tags |url=https://www.columbian.com/news/2018/sep/14/portland-police-arrest-man-allegedly-responsible-for-mook-graffiti-tags/ |work=The Columbian |date=14 September 2018 |language=en}}</ref>

The '''Nakdi Report''', also known as the '''Nakdi Document''' ({{lang-he|מסמך נקדי}}, ''{{lang|he-Latn|Mismach Nakdi}}'' ) or as the '''Nakdi guidelines''' is the document that provides ethical guidelines for use in Israel's broadcasting industry. Published as the '''''Guidelines for Coverage of News and Current Affairs''''' in 1995, the doctrine was first introduced in 1972 by the [[Israel Broadcasting Authority]]. It is named for its original author, [[Nakdimon Rogel]].<ref name=jp>{{cite news|first=Greer Fay|last=Cashman |title=Veteran journalist and broadcaster Nakdimon Rogel dies |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=248645&R=R101|work=[[Jerusalem Post]] |publisher= |date=2011-12-08 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}</ref>
Patterned after the [[BBC]]’s Editorial Guidelines (previously, the Producer Guidelines), the Document currently consists of 161 clauses and contains a comprehensive code of ethics and practice for journalists working within the IBA. It is also applied to journalists in private broadcasting, though it is not legally binding.<ref>[[Second Authority for Television and Radio]] uses a stripped-down, less detailed version of the code of conduct, which does indeed have the force of law.</ref> Since it was drawn up in 1972, the document has been revised four times - in 1979, 1985, 1995 and 1998 - and expanded to four times its original size.<ref name=Limor2002>{{cite journal | author = Limor, Y.H. |author2=Gabel, I. | year = 2002 | title = Five Versions of One Code of Ethics: The Case Study of the Israel Broadcasting Authority | journal = Journal of Mass Media Ethics | volume = 17 | issue = 2 | pages = 136–154 | doi = 10.1207/S15327728JMME1702_04 }}</ref>
==Fairness and legal challenges== It is one of the few national ethics codes to retain a version of the [[Fairness Doctrine]]. This is in addition to notions of impartiality drawn from similar European codes, which require the Authority itself to refrain from broadcasting editorials.<ref>According to Amit M. Schejter, the crucial clause is clause 22: "Beyond the word of the law the Authority has no voice, policy or point of view of its own. The Authority does not broadcast 'editorials'. The role of the Authority and its employees is to let different voices speak for themselves."</ref> Fairness, however, goes beyond mere impartiality: in order to "ensure the public’s right to receive full and reliable information alongside balanced and varied opinions", journalists are required to "solicit opposing opinion, fairly notify the public if comment was refused, and avoid becoming 'tools of response' for 'professional reaction teams.'"<ref>Rogel, Nakdimon and Schejer, Amit. ''The Nakdi Document: Guidelines for Covering News and Current Affairs'', Jerusalem: Israel Broadcasting Authority, 1998; Clauses 30-31. </ref>
The requirements to ensure varied opinion - repeated elsewhere in the document<ref>Rogel, Nakdimon and Schejer, Amit. ''The Nakdi Document: Guidelines for Covering News and Current Affairs'', Jerusalem: Israel Broadcasting Authority, 1998; Clause 24.</ref> as an enjoinder "that the pool of commentators must be varied", has caused several notable lawsuits to be filed against the IBA. Three in the 1980s were particularly notable: the first was against the landmark 1981 television miniseries ''The Pillar of Fire''. Brought by a group of Israelis of [[Sephardic]] descent who felt that the dramatised history of [[Zionism]] unfairly minimised their communities' contribution to the movement, the [[Supreme Court of Israel|Supreme Court]] indicated that in this case fairness was "irrelevant"; broadcast could not be censored, but "another aspect of the issue should be presented".<ref name=Schejter1999>{{cite journal | author = Schejter, A.M. | year = 1999 | title = The Fairness Doctrine Is Dead and Living in Israel. | journal = Federal Communications Law Journal | volume = 51 | issue = 2 | pages = 281–282 | url = https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&se=gglsc&d=5001246902 | accessdate = 2008-03-11 }}</ref> In 1982, a decision by the IBA to ban interviews with any supporters of the [[Palestinian Liberation Organisation]] in the [[Israeli-occupied territories|West Bank and Gaza]] was struck down; this case was the making of the now-legendary [[civil rights]] lawyer Amnon Zichroni. And in 1984, Rabbi [[Meir Kahane]] submitted that a similar ban on broadcasting his political statements be struck down. In a much-studied ruling that recognised racist speech was also [[free speech|protected speech]], the [[Supreme Court of Israel|High Court of Justice]] attempted to curtail the ''Zichroni vs IBA'' somewhat: [[Kach and Kahane Chai|Kach]] was permitted a "right of reply" if its positions were misrepresented, but it could not demand that its platform be broadcast, and nor could it demand the right of reply to criticism.<ref name=Schejter1999/>
==Recent concerns== More recently, the guidelines have faced a sustained barrage of criticism. After the 1996 revision appeared, a study by Yitzhak Roeh, a media studies academic at [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem|HUJI]] called it an "anachronism" and "irrelevant"<ref>Roeh, Yitzhak. "The Nakdi Document: Guidelines for Covering News and Current Affairs: A Review'', [[Ha'aretz]], 28 July 1996.</ref> Since then, right-wing groups have frequently used the Nakdi Document as a basis for documentation of what they see as [[media bias]]; the two most high-profile incidents have been litigation surrounding the broadcast of [[Avishai Raviv]]'s "swearing-in ceremony" with [[Eyal]] at [[Baruch Goldstein]]'s grave, and the campaign to get rid of [[Gabi Gazit]], whom they saw as serially breaking "the policies of public radio".<ref>Cashman, Greer. "[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1178431585287&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull The Gift of the Gab, sure, but no more Gabi]", [[Jerusalem Post]], 7 May 2007.</ref>
Although at least one study has concluded that rather than being responses to political stimuli, the various revisions of the Document have resulted in a "crystallization and implementation of normative ethical guidelines for Israeli public broadcasting",<ref name=Limor2002/> criticism that the Document contains at least some inherent bias continues to be leveled. Recently, concern that the language expected of the Israeli media was not sufficiently neutral included the complaint that the phrase "[[East Jerusalem]]" were prohibited by the guidelines.<ref name="titleLRB � Yonatan Mendel: Diary">{{cite web |url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v30/n05/mend01_.html |title=Diary |accessdate=2008-03-11 |author=Mendel, Yonatan |authorlink= |date=6 March 2008 |work= |publisher=[[London Review of Books]], vol 30, no. 5. |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref>
There have also been concerns that the Document is not detailed enough; following [[Ariel Sharon]]'s incapacitation, its ability to provide guidance balance between the private matter of his health and the public's right to know was found wanting.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Benziman | first = Uzi | title = Patient’s Condition--Severe but Stable | journal = Medicine and the Media | volume = 8 | issue = | pages = 763–780 |date=November 2006 | url = http://www.ima.org.il/imaj/ar06nov-8.pdf | accessdate = 2008-03-11 |format=PDF}}</ref> Similarly, the strictures against "melodrama" in factual broadcasting<ref>Rogel, Nakdimon and Schejer, Amit. ''The Nakdi Document: Guidelines for Covering News and Current Affairs'', Jerusalem: Israel Broadcasting Authority, 1998; Clause 115.</ref> and against filming of funerals contrary to a family's wishes<ref>Rogel, Nakdimon and Schejer, Amit. ''The Nakdi Document: Guidelines for Covering News and Current Affairs'', Jerusalem: Israel Broadcasting Authority, 1998; Clause 116</ref> have been problematic: "Sterile coverage of terrorist attacks and bereavement will not get across the dimension we need to get - the emotional dimension," according to a television executive quoted in Ha'aretz.<ref name="titleThe mourning standard - Haaretz - Israel News">{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArt.jhtml?itemNo=313956&contrassID=2&subContrassID=14&sbSubContrassID=0&listSrc=Y |title=The mourning standard |accessdate=2008-03-11 |author=Leibovich-Dar, Sara |authorlink= |date=November 2003 |format= |work= |publisher=[[Ha'aretz]] }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
